text: Nadezhda Konstantinovna KrupskayaScientific transliteration: Nade≈æda Konstantinovna Krupskaja. (; 27 February 1939)McNeal, 13. was a Russian Bolshevik and the wife of Vladimir Lenin. Like her father, Krupskaya trained to be a teacher. Krupskaya was born into a impoverished noble family. Because she was poor herself, she had strong views about making life easier for the poor. At one Marxist discussion group, she met Lenin. Soon after their meeting, Lenin was exiled to Siberia. Krupskaya was allowed to join him, on condition that they married. This could suggest a marriage of convenience, though they remained loyal. Following the 1917 Revolution, Krupskaya was at the forefront of the political scene. From 1922 to 1925, she was aligned with Stalin, Zinoviev and Kamenev against Trotsky's Left Opposition. Later, she disagreed with Stalin. She was deputy education commissar from 1929 to 1939. She had a strong influence over the Soviet educational system and the development of Soviet librarianship. == References == * Category:1869 births Category:1939 deaths Category:Feminists Category:First Ladies Category:Joseph Stalin Category:Marxists Category:People from Moscow Category:Politicians from Saint Petersburg Category:Recipients of the Order of Lenin Category:Russian Revolution Category:Russian communist politicians Category:Russian educators Category:Russian nobility Category:Russian writers Category:Soviet politicians Category:Soviet writers Category:Women's rights activists
